block.p: European Panel Reviewing Human Rights in Austria A panel of experts has been named to study Austria's human rights record and Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom Party, five months after the European Union imposed sanctions on Austria to protest the inclusion of Freedom Party members in the Austrian government.

European Panel Reviewing Human Rights in Austria A panel of experts has been named to study Austria's human rights record and Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom Party, five months after the European Union imposed sanctions on Austria to protest the inclusion of Freedom Party members in the Austrian government.

Germany Approves Tax Plan Germany's left-of-center Parliament passed a radical tax program that will slash rates and should also unleash a wave of restructuring. The vote was a remarkable victory for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder.

Mandela Urges Focus on AIDS Nelson Mandela, left, closed the 13th International Aids Conference in Durban, South Africa, by urging scientists to move beyond their concerns about South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, who has questioned whether H.I.V. causes AIDS.

Corruption Scandal in Brazil The publication of what a Brazilian newsmagazine describes as transcripts from 400 hours of wiretapped telephone calls has implicated a former presidential aide, a member of the economic cabinet, a senator and several congressional deputies in an illegal patronage and influence-trafficking network.

Heat Wave in Southeast Europe The effects of a prolonged heat wave were still being felt from Romania to southern Turkey, despite a recent easing of temperatures. The heat has claimed at least 50 lives across southeastern Europe.

Camp David Talks Kept Quiet Israeli and Palestinian leaders spent their fourth day at Camp David in secluded negotiations. A senior Palestinian official who is not inside Camp David said the Americans have begun to offer proposals to bridge the gaps between Israeli and Palestinian positions.

Fatal Landslide in Bombay The death toll from a landslide that buried a shantytown in Bombay rose to 71, but was expected to top 100. Rescuers estimated that 40 missing people could still be buried under mud and boulders. Including those killed in the landslide, 135 people have died in the monsoon storms since Wednesday, the Press Trust of India news agency said.

Jury Orders Big Tobacco To Pay $144.8 Billion A jury in Miami imposed the largest damage award in United States history, ordering the tobacco industry to pay $144.8 billion in punitive damages to 500,000 sick Florida smokers. Tobacco executives called the award ridiculous and said it would push the companies into bankruptcy.

U.S. Cleared in Waco Deaths An advisory panel of five jurors found that federal officials were not liable in the deaths of nearly 80 Branch Davidians who were killed in the 1993 raid and standoff at the sect's compound near Waco, Tex.

Tapes Don't Equal Charges Videotapes of police beatings made by onlookers are increasingly common, and although the images are powerful, the officers captured on film often face no criminal charges, a review of 18 recent cases shows.

Vote to Repeal Estate Tax The Senate voted to repeal the federal estate tax, brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton and giving Republicans at least a symbolic victory on an issue at the top of their election-year agenda.

Reluctant to Join Gore Representative Richard A. Gephardt, left, has emerged high on Al Gore's list of possible running mates, people close to the vice president say. But Mr. Gephardt's advisers insist that he wants his name scratched.
Bush-Pataki Ticket Explored George W. Bush met privately with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York to talk about the vice presidency.

Pilots and F.A.A. End Dispute Airline pilots and the Federal Aviation Administration ended a safety dispute that had led pilots to sometimes refuse an instruction to land. The airlines said the pilots' refusal added to airport delays.

Letter Is Called a Forgery The Florida authorities are investigating a letter that purports to be from Gov. Jeb Bush to a Florida member of Congress that the governor's office says is a forgery. The letter claims to detail Mr. Bush's position on legislation before Congress to ban gambling on the Internet.

Fears of West Nile Virus Keep Campers Indoors Children taking part in the 92nd Street Y's summer camp spent their ''overnight under the stars'' indoors because of parents' fears about disease-carrying mosquitoes.
Brawley Case Reverberates Alton H. Maddox Jr., who was found liable for defamation in the Tawana Brawley case two years ago, vowed to reverse the verdict and said he refuses to pay the damage award.

Bush Gives a Hand to Lazio George W. Bush offered his support for Representative Rick A. Lazio's Senate bid, belittling Hillary Rodham Clinton with a familiar critique before an audience of Conservative Party donors in Manhattan.

A Maid's Suit Is Settled A federal lawsuit in which a domestic worker accused her employer, a diplomat from Bahrain, of keeping her in virtual peonage has been settled out of court, the woman's lawyer said.

Finding Strength in Unity Substitute teachers exchanged horror stories and survival strategies in Washington at their first national conference, an effort to raise pay, benefits and working conditions.

A Move to Lure Teachers The New York State Board of Regents voted to create an alternative certification program for teachers, hoping to draw people from other professions into the field to alleviate an acute shortage.

Jan Karski A liaison officer of the Polish underground who infiltrated the Warsaw Ghetto and a German concentration camp and carried the first eyewitness accounts of the Holocaust to a mostly disbelieving West, he was 86.

Railway Merger Looks Unlikely The Burlington Northern Santa Fe and Canadian National Railway companies, which were planning to create a rail system spanning North America, lost an appeal and will probably end up scuttling their proposed $6 billion merger.

Takeover of Reliance Collapses A planned takeover of Saul Steinberg's Reliance Group Holdings collapsed amid worries that Reliance would be unable to pay debts. Leucadia National, which agreed in May to buy Reliance for $295 million in stock, said it was unwilling to proceed with the transaction.

Questions for 'Big Brother' CBS said it was looking into a report that William Collins, one of the participants in ''Big Brother,'' is an associate of the militant anti-Semitic black leader Khalid Muhammad. But CBS said it saw no reason to remove Mr. Collins from the show.

Pillsbury Purchase Pending The board of General Mills is meeting Sunday to approve its acquisition of Pillsbury from Diageo P.L.C. for $10.5 billion in cash and stock, according to executives close to the negotiations. If the board approves the deal, the companies will announce it on Monday, the executives said.

Stocks Rise Across the Board Nasdaq jumped 71.32 points, or 1.7 percent, to 4,246.18, its highest close in more than three months. The Dow climbed 24.04 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,812.75, and the S.&P. 500 rose 14.14 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,509.98.

Correction: July 18, 2000, Tuesday An article yesterday about network television interviews with Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush referred incorrectly in some copies to Mr. Gore's position on the death penalty. He is in favor of it, not opposed.
